Award.AwardTitle: TWC SBE: TTP Option: Medium: Collaborative: EPICA: Empowering People to Overcome Information Controls and Attacks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project studies the security of representative personalized services, such as search engines, news aggregators, and on-line targeted advertising, and identifies vulnerabilities in service components that can be exploited by pollution attacks to deliver contents intended by attackers.

This project also develops defense-in-depth countermeasures against pollution attacks. These include new server-side mechanisms to prevent the various cross-site-request-forgery schemes that allow an attacker to insert actions. The defense mechanisms also include a distributed data collection, measurement and analysis framework to detect anomalies in browsing behaviors and information contents that are indicative of pollution of user profiles or population preferences. The new information analysis techniques use machine learning and natural language processing to identify differences (e.g., missing information) that are significant or important to a user. The project also develops tools to alert users and guide them to understand and repair profiles, and studies regulatory models to incentivize the industry to adopt a more transparent practice.

This project develops an evaluation framework to facilitate the development and adoption of technologies. The evaluation plan includes user studies involving real, diverse user groups on the Internet.

To transition technologies to practice, this project makes the tools freely available, and deploys data collection and measurement systems on the Internet. This project also educates users about pollution attacks and engages with users to improve the usability of the tools.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This primary outcomes of this work included the first in depth understanding of users mental models of privacy-enhancing tools such as Tor browser and virtual private networks and their current behaviors using these tools. In addition, the project resulted in the first data set of the prevalence of disclosures of social media endorsements on two platforms, YouTube and Pinterest as well as evidence that users do not understand current disclosure formats encouraged by the Federal Trade commission. The intellectual merit of this work has advanced our understanding of how to better design privacy-enhancing tools and tools for helping users uncover misleading online information as well as what cognitive biases influence users privacy and security behaviors online.

The project supported 4 PhD students in various project stages, one of which has graduated to work in industry. The project outcomes were also published at top tier conferences and the results were disseminated in multiple blog posts on the Center for Information Technology Policy center at Princeton University to reach policy-makers and an audience beyond computer science. In addition, the PI and students gave talks at an computational social science event in Cape Town, South Africa, various US universities, and one directed at over 500 high school students.

This project also had broad impacts beyond academia. Specifically, the user interface improvements we identified for Tor browser were communicated to the Tor user experience team who altered the browser's interface with our input. Secondly, the results about the prevalence of affiliate marketing on social media were  communicated directly to the Federal Trade Commission to influence policy guidelines on social media endorsements on the Internet. The long term impacts of this project are to inform the design of a new host of tools for ensuring Internet users understand the pros and cons of various privacy-enhancing tools and can recognize misleading online information.
